speech.para: I do not have the concerns that the opposition does with the Democrats. It is a devised alternative. It is critical to the prospect of the republic coming in on 6 November that we stick with the question that they put forward. I could not see any possibility that there is going to be any change of mind. Notwithstanding the events of the GST and the environment legislation just before the winter break, I have confidence that the Democrats on this occasion will not make it three in a row but will stand firm on an important point to help this nation go into the next century with an Australian as head of state.

The second matter that the House of Representatives has disagreed with is an amendment I moved on behalf of the Greens to section 61 of the proposed Constitution which would ensure that the Prime Minister could not manipulate the system to keep an incumbent President in place long after that President's term of office of five years had expired. The mechanism to do this is a simple amendment that the Prime Minister be given 30 days after the expiry of a President's term to ensure that the new President was in place. The incumbent President's office would expire within 30 days at the end of five years, and that is how it should be. I put it to the committee, which is somewhat distracted at the moment by this rapid turn of events, that we focus on this matter.

In its response to us, the House of Representatives—that is, the government, which, by the way, has quite sloppily attributed the change here to section 60 of the intended Constitution instead of section 61—has said that section 61 should allow for the continuation of the incumbent President who had previously been appointed with the support of both the Prime Minister and Leader of the Opposition beyond 30 days. So be it, but the end of term is no longer in the hands of the Leader of the Opposition as well as the Prime Minister, or for that matter the parliament. It is simply the Prime Minister who can allow the incumbent President to stay there as long as whoever the Prime Minister of the day is wants them to.

We ought not allow that situation to arise. We ought to make sure that there will be five years notice as to the end of a term of a President and that the Prime Minister is not given this backdoor route to not selecting another President and having her or him in place in due time. It is a very important clarification of the situation. It is an important direction to the Prime Minister to make sure that they treat the matter of appointing a new President seriously and get it done in time. I stand firm on that. I certainly hope that the committee will stand firm on that regardless of what happens to the wording of the question to be put to the people of Australia on 6 November, although I reiterate that we should stand firm on that matter as well.

talk.start.para: —The question we have come down to this afternoon is this: do we want a referendum or not? Over the last couple of days, and indeed over the last few hours with all sorts of messages flying around, it has become very clear that the government is going to press ahead with what is a loaded question and one which we would argue, and this is why we moved to amend it, is going to bias the result. However, we do not believe that we in this place should prevent the referendum from going ahead. Therefore, unfortunately, we will not be insisting at this time.
—Shame on you.

—Thank you, Senator Brown. It is a regret to us that we have been forced into this position by a Prime Minister who has made it very clear time and time again that he does not want a republic. But I do think that the Australian people expect us to go ahead with a referendum on 6 November. Obviously his alternative was going to be to reject it again, which is what we would have expected to happen later tonight, but then consider the option of leaving it for six months—in other words, three months later—with the question passed in the House of Representatives. While that is a possibility—indeed, I think it is probably a very remote one—I suspect that the majority of this government would want to put to one side permanently this whole issue of a republic.

speech.para: What has been a difficult decision for us is one, however, that all of us have taken together. As you know, we spent some time this afternoon discussing and rediscussing what we were planning to do. We still firmly believe that the question we posed—the simple question asking the Australian people whether or not they wanted a republic and then leaving the arguments to the yes and no case—was the best way to proceed. We have to keep in mind that we have a government, particularly a Prime Minister, that does not want a republic. As I think all my Democrat colleagues agree, the Australian people at least expect the referendum to go ahead. The course of that is probably going to be influenced by our decision now to let the loaded question proceed, but that is our decision today.

talk.start.para: —What a party of bucklers. As I said in a previous debate, the Democrats are becoming political poodles—people who run around barking at everybody and then jump into the first lap available. Certainly, they take the first direction available. I believe the Prime Minister would have backed off on this issue—as he has done on a number of other related issues in the last two weeks—because he knows the political cost of it if he did not.

speech.para: It is a shameful outcome as far as the Democrats are concerned. It is going to make the question more difficult. It is going to increase the no vote. It is going to increase the likelihood that we will not get the result we want, even though I have faith in the Australian people to vote the way their own feelings on this dictate, notwithstanding the impediment of the long question put before them.

Here we have a pattern which is now becoming the pattern of the Democrats—that is, a difficult situation, a public commitment to a course of action, then a little pressure applied by the Prime Minister and they buckle. The question is: why put up an alternative to the Prime Minister in the first place if you do not have any intention of standing firm on it? These are important matters. This is not just an alternative form of words. These are alternatives which can determine the outcome of whether or not we become a republic after 6 November. Collectively, the Democrats have taken a weak course of action. Collectively, they are frightened by the prospect of a Prime Minister making a mistake. They are covering inexcus able courses of action that the Prime Minister might take in the future.

Do they really believe that the Prime Minister would have called off the referendum because he did not get his way with the words? Of course, he would not have. He would have acceded to this form of words if the Democrats stood firm. He does not have to now. He will say, `I wasn't going to change my mind,' but he would have. It would have been better for the Australian people; it would have been better for the course of this historic decision that we have to make. Eighteen million Australians face a more difficult question because of the perceived intransigence of the Prime Minister and the historic weakness of nine Democrat senators. I expected better of them.

I thought after the reaction to their cave in on the GST that they might have stood more strongly this time. I thought after their cave in on years of principle in the environment legislation, which they passed—including its forest destructive components—just before the winter break, that they might have had time to think about that and strengthen a bit. Now three times in a row they have caved in on matters of enormous importance to their own constituency and to Australians. Ten to 15 million voters are going to have a more difficult question to face because of the irresolute, vacillatory and, finally, cave in nature of the Democrats. So be it.

It has been an interesting debate. I am glad we are going to have a referendum. I am sorry that the Democrats could not make it easier for the Australian people. I am sorry that they can come up with good suggestions but are equally inclined then to fail to stand by those good suggestions, as is the case here.

We know now the pattern for the next two or three years in this place. The Prime Minister certainly knows what to do if he wants the Democrats to cave in. He simply has to stare at them and they will look down, they will look away first, they will back off. That is part of the prescription in this place. The Democrats have to live with it.

talk.start.para: —I also express my amazement at this amazingly pathetic climb down. It was just a little while ago that we were talking about whether the Democrats would or would not climb down, and they assured us that they would not. What have they done? They have come in here and said, `The Prime Minister has said that we will not have a referendum; therefore, we will do what he wants.' The old sheepdog started barking and the Democrats started scurrying away. Aren't you an easy touch for the Prime Minister? His master's voice speaks and the Democrats follow.

speech.para: Your supporters may well ask: what do you stand for anymore? What do you stand for when you say yes? What do you stand for when you say `green'? What do you stand for when you come in here and say you will do one thing? Forever after this, whenever you come in here and say, `We believe in this,' we will all go away thinking, `They believe in this, but then again they might believe in that and then again they might believe in nothing.' That is exactly the message you are sending out to your supporters. What does this do to your credibility? This is the biggest backflip in the Senate's history for quite some time. You are all sitting there asking us to believe that you have merit on your side because the Prime Minister has said, `If you do not agree with what I say you will not get a referendum.'

Do not forget that 60 per cent of Australians want a republic. This Prime Minister has been pushed around by public opinion time and time again over recent weeks. He has changed the question in response to public opinion. Do you think he can get out of this place today, tomorrow, this weekend and say, `Look, they did not agree with what I wanted so they are not going to have a referendum'? Do you think he can get away with that politically and credibly? Of course he cannot. If he can get away with it for the first five or six hours, depending on what happens in the press gallery, he would not get away with it for too long in public because the public reservoir of support for a republic has been strong and continues to be strong.

If he wants to continue to offend 60 per cent of Australians by saying, `You cannot have a referendum even though I promised you could have one,' then it will be on his head. But no, the Australian Democrats basically said, `The PM's barked at us and we have scurried away.' What do you stand for? You have devalued your status, devalued your credibility and devalued the concept of negotiation. Bring back Senator Harradine to hold the balance of power. He knew how to negotiate. He knew how to get things out of government. He knew you did not buckle on day one. I will say this, Senator Harradine, although quite often you disagree with me and you disagree with me now: you would develop your position and you would hang out and you would get a good price; you would not sell out at bargain basement prices, as the Australian Democrats have done. As I said of the Australian Democrats, you are sending the message to your supporters that you do not have any willpower and you do not believe in anything.

I said yesterday that in the skills of negotiation the Australian Democrats have exposed themselves as no longer being the fairies at the bottom of the garden but being this Senate's child-care centre. I think government in this country needs a greater degree of maturity in approaching issues like this. We have wasted the time of this parliament today because you have not known what you stood for: you stood for one thing this morning and another thing this afternoon. If that is the way you want to continue running the operation of this Senate—coming on after the GST, after the environment legislation—you will continue to be easy meat for the government and you will continue to be easy meat for a pernicious John Howard agenda.

At the end of today, had the Prime Minister walked away and said, `No referendum,' he could have looked to the rest of Australia a stodgy little spoiler. Let us remember: each part of this process, each episode, each chapter, he has tilted the balance: pro-monarchist, anti-republican. You have just given him a green light to do it at the final count. If it is a close count, it will depend on the question asked. That is pretty clear from the Neilsen polls. If that question asked goes against us then we will look back to this day when the Democrats folded on a core issue of fairness and reasonableness.

talk.start.para: —I want to respond briefly to some of the fairly predictable political attacks. Equally predictably they had little policy substance to them. I have commented a few times in other debates on Senator Brown's contributions in previous recent debates in this place. In response to him, I said that he had a great career as an environmentalist but had been a politician for a very long time now and, as often happens with people who are politicians for a long time, he tends to find it hard to think of what else he can do. But he is obviously starting to line up for another career now. He is warming up to his new career as a fortune teller, having predicted that without a shadow of a doubt, unequivocally, the PM will back down, that if we insist on this as a Senate the PM will back down. I am glad you have those skills as a fortune teller. Perhaps you now have another career that you can move on to.

speech.para: He also stated that he is glad we are going to have a referendum, yet he wants us to vote in a way that jeopardises that possibility. Nobody knows for sure what the Prime Minister would or would not have done. But the Democrats specifically tested him today by putting forward what is clearly a fairer question, and his response and the response of the House of Representatives was not to support that fairer question. But the bottom line is that I am certainly glad—and I am sure the public will be glad—that they are going to have an opportunity to vote on whether or not we will become a republic.

Senator Brown says he is glad, so I am pleased that he is happy that the Democrats are facilitating and ensuring, not taking any risk at all, that that will be the outcome, that the public will have a chance to have their say. As someone who will be urging them to vote yes—as I think the previous Democrat speaker, Senator Lees, and her deputy, Senator Stott Despoja, will also be doing—I will be keen to ensure that the benefits of Australia moving to a republic are explained during the course of the referendum campaign.

The other important point I want to make is in relation to the suggestion that somehow or other, because the Democrats decided in this case that it was not appropriate to insist, that means it is not clear what we stand for. I would be happy if Senator Bolkus wants to take that as a standard of measurement for the ALP. I hope that means that they will never, ever at any stage in the future decide and have never, ever at any stage in the past decided not to insist on amendments. Even in the short time I have been in this chamber I know the opposition have decided at times not to insist on their own amendments. That is part of the political process when you have to weigh up whether or not something is worth risking losing altogether or worth persevering with. The Democrats' view is that it was not worth risking losing the possibility of the Australian people having their say on whether or not we become a republic. I am sure they will be quite pleased that the politicians have ceased arguing about this and that they will get a chance to have a debate and that it has been moved away from the politicians.

It is probably worth reminding Senator Brown, who also continued with the predictable words about backdowns and shameful cave-ins, et cetera, that it was his change in position, as he reminded this chamber yesterday, that enabled the Constitutional Convention to occur. The Senate was not supportive of the proposal that was being put forward in that regard and he obviously made a considered judgment that, whilst he did not support the proposal that was being put forward as an ideal approach, it was better to have some sort of convention than not. That was a position he took; others disagreed. But I think it was quite valid for him to do so. Indeed, as part of that convention, that highlights why we have had so much consultation on this issue for so long. The issue of the question, amongst many others, has been part of the public consultations, part of the parliamentary committee inquiry.

He made a choice at that time to change his position. I do not know whether or not the Democrats or others abused him and called it a `shameful sell-out', `backdown' or `cave-in'. Certainly he felt he could justify that change of position to enable something to go ahead that he did not see as ideal but did not want to risk losing altogether. This is something that the Democrats believe we can justify because we do not believe it is worth jeopardising the Australian people losing the opportunity to vote on whether or not we move towards a republic. I, for one, certainly hope that they vote yes to that question and we can move on to some of the other important issues that the nation needs to address in the next century.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the comments of my colleagues. A majority of the Democrat party room has determined that we will not insist on the amendment, and I am very conscious of the fact that it is my amendment that I moved on behalf of my party and that it had the unanimous support of my party. It is very wrong and quite inaccurate for any honourable member in this place—and I defy any honourable member and anyone else in the community or the media—to suggest that we indicated earlier in the week that we would not consider our position after the debate took place this morning or after the vote was taken. All along we have indicated that the last thing we wanted to do was to jeopardise the process or the passage of this legislation. I would like nothing better—in fact, it is incredibly tempting—than to insist, but this is not a game. This is not a debate that is worthy of catcalls, poodles, and the whole menagerie that has been thrown at us this afternoon. This is not a game; this is quite a serious vote and a referendum is quite a serious event.

speech.para: I am in a rather invidious position because, as a member of the yes committee, I want nothing better than a referendum to take place and for us to have a republic. I know perfectly well that a question plays a pivotal part in that process. That is why we sought to ensure the fairest, simplest and most accurate question be put before the Australian people.

I think the Prime Minister should hang his head in shame. He is not a statesman. He did not respond to an amendment that was passed earlier by the majority in this place by saying, `Yes, it is appropriate not to buck precedent.' He has not given the people who want to push the yes case the opportunity to frame that question or, at least, to ensure that the question is framed in the most favourable way, a la: do you support a free and democratic election? We know that there is a bias against winning constitutional referenda in this country. We know how difficult it was to get eight out of 42 over so many years and we know how important the question was to that process. That is why the Democrats sought to break a stalemate we saw occurring earlier this week.

It is unfair to suggest that we said, `Yes, we will take this to the end. We will go to the barricades because our question is the best.' I indicated, on behalf of my colleagues, that we were very concerned that this might disrupt the referendum process in some way. This is not a game, as a previous speaker seemed to indicate; this is not us being weak. This is a tough decision and one that we have spent a lot of time debating and discussing.

The Prime Minister has not stared me down; the Prime Minister does not stare at me. He does not seem to invite me into his office on too many occasions to discuss these types of issues. But I and my colleagues have had to juggle the possibility that not only would the question not be changed but also that a referendum would not take place. Contrary to the comments of Senator Brown, or his interjections in relation to consultation, there have been many views expressed to us this week from different members of the community through different media—through letters, faxes, emails and phone calls. People are concerned that this process may be held up in some way. I have spoken to republicans who would dearly love a delay. I would not mind an extra three to six months to ensure that we win this campaign, despite the odds, and there are great odds.

We have a biased question; we have a Prime Minister who said that he would opt out of this debate and take a back seat, and yet has interfered every step of the way. Probably for one of the first times in our history, we have a Prime Minister who is putting forward a question but is not prepared to support it. I think it is shameful and I do not think the fault should lie with non-govern ment parties in this house. We should not squabble amongst ourselves during this debate, and nor should we squabble among ourselves as republicans because there is a clear majority in this chamber—and I include, of course, government members in that list.

We should put the fault where it belongs: with a Prime Minister who is scared that this country might move into the next century and the next millennium with an Australian head of state. He is scared that we might throw off his notions of a 1950s Australia and white picket fences and get the opportunity to move into the rest of the world among a friendly family of nations in the Commonwealth as a mature, independent and confident nation. He is so scared that a clear majority of Australians want that opportunity that he is prepared every step of the way in this process to muddle, obfuscate and rig the question. That is shameful and the fault lies with him.

The Democrats, as the expert legislators I like to think we have been over the last 20-odd years, have done our job. We have tried to ameliorate the worst parts of legislation. We have tried to rectify the defects—and there are some in this model being presented to Australians—and we have tried to ensure a role for the Senate in the dismissal process. We have tried to stop the entrenchment of the two-party system through this process of appointment and we have tried very hard to ensure that the power of the executive is not embellished and increased and put into our Constitution in a way it has never been before. We have tried to ensure that the question is simple, fair, accurate, straightforward—all of these things—and we have lost. We acknowledge that.

Unfortunately, I do not think that pressing this amendment now will necessarily change some of those factors. People know that while I belong to a pro-republican party—and certainly I suggest that every colleague I sit with today is a republican—that does not mean we do not have commitments to different models or that we have not voted differently from each other today.

The majority of my colleagues opposed the legislation in its final reading today with good reason. There are flaws in this model. But I suspect many of us will go to the campaign in November and, I hope, vote yes despite some of those obstacles. I am not sure whether those obstacles would be ironed out with the pressing of this amendment. I do not know for sure, because I am not a fortune teller like Senator Brown. My colleagues and I have made the decision today that we are not prepared—in some ways unfortunately—to play constitutional chicken with the Australian people. We are not prepared to test the limits of this one, just in case the Prime Minister calls our bluff—that is, the bluff of all those who voted for the amendment today—and just in case he says that there will be no referendum. The Australian people now expect that referendum. As much as many of us would like to see it as a plebiscite, with a different question or with a different model, I think we have to proceed. But it is a risk, especially for those of us who will be voting yes and who know how important the weight of the question and the title is.

We are not frightened of the prospect of the Prime Minister staring us down, as Senator Brown would have us believe. We are genuinely frightened by the prospect of no referendum and that we may be giving up an opportunity to vote on this issue. That aside, judging from community feedback, we would be denying people the opportunity that they expect on 6 November. Do not get me wrong, Mr Temporary Chairman: my faith—such that it is—in this government and in the Prime Minister is completely shaken. They had a better question and an appropriate title, and yet the government and the Prime Minister chose to reject that, not us. The fault clearly, fairly and squarely lies with the Prime Minister. My colleagues understand that, and for those reasons we will not be voting to press the amendment, no matter how tempting or unfortunate that may be.

talk.start.para: —We all know the Constitution now provides for the House of Representatives, where the Prime Minister has the majority, to go it alone. As has been stated by previous speakers, if these amendments are pressed, the Prime Minister can call our bluff. He knows—as well as anybody who has been around here for a while knows—that could be done in such a way that the question and other matters relating to the establishment of a republic could go to the people in a less satisfactory manner than we have here. The best that can come out of it is what the government is prepared to do.

speech.para: Give the Prime Minister the opportunity and there is no doubt in my mind that one of two things would happen. One, he would say that he did his best, that he tried to get it through the parliament and that he did not succeed. Then he could put the matter aside. Two, either he could go with what we have here or he could go with a more unsatisfactory proposition. As Senator Lees said, this is either a referendum or not a referendum. Some of the things that have been said about the Australian Democrats in regard to this matter are a bit unfair. Senator Bolkus, you may have wished me well in respect of your suggestion wishing that I come back to the balance of power—I would gratefully decline that invitation. If the motion needs the 39 votes here, I am intending to not insist upon the amendments that the Senate has included in the proposal that went down to the House of Representatives and came back with the House of Representatives disagreeing.

talk.start.para: —I have a couple of points, Mr Temporary Chairman, in reply to Senator Harradine.
—I thought you had a plane to catch.
—The 4.30 plane has gone; the 6.30 one is still to go.
—The 5.30 is warming up.

—The 5.30 has just about gone—that is right. I am resigned to spending another night with you, Senator Harradine. I have to explain that somehow to my wife; I will be on the phone very soon. A couple of points need to be made. There are two amendments. I traverse the referendum question first. The opposition's view is that, if the Democrats change their minds—and they have indicated they will—and support the question proposed by the government, we will not be frustrating the legislation by insisting on the other amendment that was carried by the Senate. That was amendment No. 3, which gives a 30-day period after the expiration of a President's term for a replacement President to be appointed. We do not think that issue is sufficient to frustrate the workings of this place and keep it going any longer.

speech.para: The other point that I wish to make in respect of your point, Senator Harradine, is that it is a legal point that is sustainable. You are right that, in terms of the Constitution, the Prime Minister does have that power. But I think he would be seen in an enormously bad light by the public and media were he, at this stage of the process, to grab the ball and run off on his own with it and put his own question to the public. I think that was an option which was probably not politically available to him. The opposition considered that option, but we thought that it was something that was not within the bounds of political acceptance. We therefore come to facing this issue now and, as I indicated earlier, we will be pursuing our position in support of the Australian Democrat amendment and withstanding the motion moved by Senator Ellison on behalf of the government.

This also comes on a day when there has been an enormous reaction across the country to the other action taken by the Australian Democrats—that is, action to replace `custodianship' with `kinship' in the preamble. I will not discuss the preamble now—we have some time for that later, although not much time—but this does raise the question of process. These are issues that go to the character of the nation and to the building of national unity and spirit. In such processes as we have had today and yesterday, we have proposals being developed under threat by a Prime Minister and proposals being developed in secret. And, with respect to the preamble, at a time when Australia was starting to realise that you do not take decisions affecting indigenous Australians without full consultation—something that Senator Ridgeway has impressed upon me quite consistently over the years—you have junked those sorts of principles on the most important legislation. It has been developed in secret and under threat, and that does not do much to build the character of this nation and pride in our institutions and the direction in which we are going.

It would be a lot better if we had a Prime Minister who was prepared to take charge of a progressive forward agenda for Australia, not one who keeps on falling back to the forties, fifties and sixties for his inspiration. It would be good to have a Prime Minister who was prepared to represent and reflect the aspirations, will and direction of the public, not one who always wants to take us back. That is the point of regret I make at this particular part of the debate.

talk.start.para: —The other matter that is important here, and Senator Bolkus referred to it, is the Greens amendment that the house has disagreed with: that the Prime Minister should not have the opportunity to extend a President's tenure more than 30 days beyond the five-year period in office. If we do get a rogue Prime Minister—like a Joh Bjelke-Petersen or a Robin Gray—in office, that is just the sort of manipulation that could occur. This is an important matter. I am sorry that the opposition is not going to insist on it, because I think, under the circumstances, that it is one that the Prime Minister would accede to at this stage.

speech.para: It seems to be a technical matter at the moment but, further down the line, it would be very important to be able to put a halter on a Prime Minister who was doing the wrong thing and who had no restraint put on him, such as in the appointment of a President, by the parliament or the Leader of the Opposition. There is no doubt that the Democrats would have buckled on it, however, in the mood that they are in at the moment. I just want to put it on record that, in the circumstances, this amendment is not getting the important consideration that it ought to. I want it put on the record very clearly that my position is not to accede to the message from the House of Representatives on either of these points of dispute with the Senate.

speech.para: Schedule, page 3 (lines 4 to 26), omit the Preamble, substitute:

Having come together in 1901, relying on God, as a Federation under the Crown, and the Commonwealth of Australia being now a sovereign democracy, our people drawn from many nations, we the people of Australia:

celebrating our unity;

This is where we have the clear option of the preamble that I have spoken about quite frequently during this debate. I will read it for a final time. It is half the length of the Democrat-government preamble, it is more succinct and it is better. The preamble reads:

Having come together in 1901, relying on God, as a Federation under the Crown, and the Commonwealth of Australia being now a sovereign democracy, our people drawn from many nations, we the people of Australia:

speech.para: I think it much more succinctly describes us than the wordy compromise that has come forward from the government and the Democrats. It has simple sentences and simple statements. It covers every aspect that most of us have been trying to express in the debate about what we need in a preamble. talk.start.para: —I move the opposition amendment on sheet 1498:

speech.para: Schedule, page 3 (line 12), omit "war", substitute "conflict".

This amendment seeks to overcome what clearly is a drafting error—that is the best thing I can say for it—made by the government and the Democrats in their haste to cobble together this awful preamble. I refer to that part of the preamble which says:
never forgetting the sacrifices of all who defended our country and our liberty in time of war;

My colleague Graham Edwards, the member for Cowan in the other place—a Vietnam veteran who, as we all know, was very badly wounded in that war—pointed out that the Vietnam War was never a declared war. There are many other conflicts that our soldiers have been involved in since Federation which were not actually formally declared wars. Even in recent years our servicepeople—men and women—have been part of UN peacekeeping forces. You would not say that they were involved in a war, but they were carrying out the duties of the United Nations, in which we were very proud to participate. Those servicepeople have distinguished themselves and Australia greatly by the way in which they provided that service in various, sometimes remote, places.

A number of cases come to mind. We had the involvement of our Australian troops in the Cambodian peace settlement. We had Australian troops in Namibia. We had Australian troops in Western Sahara. We had Australian troops who, via our involvement with the British Army, have actually served in Bosnia, Macedonia, the Balkans, Iran, et cetera, and have all distinguished themselves very well. I have not been given a comprehensive list of the peacekeeping forces that we have served in, but there is one thing that is for certain: unfortunately, there will be further demand on Australian servicepeople—men and women—to serve in UN peacekeeping forces into the next century. They are not declared wars, by any definition, but they are conflicts and our service people put their lives at risk.

We also, of course, had—apart from the Vietnam War—during the fifties and the sixties the Malayan emergency and the Indonesian confrontation. Again, they were not declared wars; they were insurgencies, whatever form of words you use. We believe that the word `conflict' is a much better description than the word `war'. A Vietnam veteran like Graham Edwards feels it necessary to raise in parliament and in public that as a Vietnam veteran he feels the use of the word `war' rather than the word `conflict' could be taken as discrimination against the service of Australian soldiers in the Vietnam War.

The controversy in Australia about our involvement in the Vietnam War by those of us, including myself, who strongly opposed our involvement in that war in the 1960s was never directed against the servicemen. We accept that some of those were unfortunately conscripted, often against their will, to go and fight. We never directed our opposition to their service. They were called on by the government of the day to go and serve. In our view, it was the government of the day that was at fault.

Subsequently, Vietnam veterans have always felt that their contribution and service to their country as called on by the government was never properly recognised in the same way as the service people returning from the Great War, the Second World War and the Korean War were accepted and recognised. Even today as shadow minister for veterans' affairs I come across groups of Vietnam veterans who still feel anguish that they were forgotten and ignored on their return. It was not until the late 1980s and the coming home march that recognition towards those servicepeople started for their contribution in the Vietnam War as required by the government.

I think Graham Edwards has it right. We ought to get these things correct in the preamble so we do not use in an untoward or unwitting way a word which says that there are two levels of acceptance in that the First World War and Second World War were real wars but the Vietnam War was not a real war because it was not declared. We should never distinguish between those in the services who, to use that phrase, put themselves in harm's way in the service of their country as required by the elected government of the day, whatever that controversy may mean.

Again, I emphasise to the committee that the drafting of this preamble, which was obviously rushed and made with no consultation, proves this point: when you do it that way, you make bad mistakes. This is going to be put to the people to vote on in the referendum to be made part of our Constitution. As I said when speaking in favour of Senator Brown's amendment of the preamble drafted by Gareth Evans, Senator Brown and Senator Stott Despoja, when you take time and have a wider consultation you get a better result compared to this one. Therefore, on behalf of the veterans community in particular, I commend this amendment to the committee.

talk.start.para: —For the record, the government opposes this amendment. The comments I made previously still stand. The term `war' is used in a generic sense as it is used in common parlance. The member for Cowan has been referred to, but the former Deputy Prime Minister, Tim Fischer, was a veteran as well. He has said that he is quite happy with the term `war'. It is obvious we are not going to please everybody all the time, and the Prime Minister has already said that, but we believe that this is an appropriate term.

I do not think I need to add much more to the debate than that.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the comments made by Senator Bolkus. talk.start.para: —I indicate that we will not be calling a division at this stage of the process but will be calling one at the third reading stage.
—Senator Brown, you indicated that you will not be moving Greens amendment No. 2. Would you move amendment No. 1.
—I move Greens amendment No. 1:

speech.para: (1) Schedule, page 3 (line 5), omit "With hope in God, the Commonwealth", substitute "The Commonwealth".

I have already given the argument for this amendment, which would take away the first four words in the proposed preamble—those words being `With hope in God'. I move this amendment because I believe those words are very restrictive. As I said earlier, we have gone from having reliance on the Almighty 100 years ago to the word `hope' and we are in a much more secular society where this does not express the spiritual beliefs of some millions of Australians, particularly young Australians, as we go into the next century.

I am in no way wanting to truncate those people who do have a belief in God with a capital `G' and with the very restricted meaning that our culture has placed upon that down the line. Everybody should be free to fight for their beliefs. I will be at the forefront of fighting for everybody's right to express their spirituality in their own way. talk.start.para: —I will not repeat the arguments from earlier today where it was indicated that we would not be supporting this amendment. I do not think I need to canvass those arguments again. We went through them to some extent yesterday as well.

—Senator Brown is revisiting God. Honourable senators will recall that in late 1997 Senator Brown attempted to do away with public prayer in the parliament; he is now attempting to remove reference to God in the Constitution. Leaders of all nations must recognise that they do not have the power to rule absolutely. Failure to acknowledge that leads to human rights violations. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights in fact was drafted largely by persons who had a deep commitment to God and who were influenced by natural law philosophies. speech.para: Senator Brown mentions the word `secular'. To be secular is one thing, but to deliberately expunge from the Australian Constitution an expression of hope in the Creator is quite another. talk.start.para: —This is a bill which proposes to amend the Customs Act 1901 to provide that customs duty is not payable on goods imported on a temporary basis for use in the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games, the Sydney 2000 Paralympic Games, certain events in the Sydney Cultural Olympics and a number of events leading up to these Olympics. No duty will be payable on these goods on the proviso that such goods are exported by the end of the year 2000. A regulation to this extent has already been made. The bill essentially gives legislative support to this regulation.

speech.para: The goods which will be covered by the provision are the vast amounts of infrastructure items such as desks, tents, chairs, et cetera, which will be—and in some cases already have been—brought in by SOCOG. Also covered will be motor vehicles, telecast technology and any other goods which will be imported specifically for use in relation to the Olympics and related events and which will be exported again once these events are completed. Duty will become payable if the goods are used in contravention of the regulations—for example, for a purpose other than one related to the Olympics or associated events, or if the goods are not exported before 31 December 2000 without the grant of an extension of time.

In order to ensure that there is a clear audit trail for all temporarily imported goods, the bill provides Customs with the power to demand information regarding the goods on importation. Owners of the goods must also notify Customs of their intention to export the goods without entry documentation so that Customs has a complete record of the movement of the goods. The bill will reduce the administrative complexity involved with the large numbers of the goods temporarily imported into Australia for the Olympics and related events and will ensure that Customs is able to track these goods to prevent them from illegally entering the domestic market.

The opposition supports the passage of this bill through the parliament, although it is a matter of concern that SOCOG has a need to import so much of the infrastructure for the conduct of the Olympics. It is a concern to the opposition that Australian companies were not able to win tenders to supply these goods. There is also a concern on the part of the opposition about the technology which will be coming in with broadcasters. It highlights the fact that Australia appears to be behind other nations in that regard. The question must be asked: why are our major television stations behind in digital technology? One wonders whether the government is looking at the initiatives in this bill to reduce administrative problems to see how they could be applied across the board. Having said that, the opposition will be supporting this bill.

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator O'Brien for his contribution to the debate. This bill relates to customs preparations for the Olympics, and the bill has two functions. For goods temporarily imported for the Olympics, the bill sets 31 December 2000 as the last date for those goods to be exported, otherwise duties and taxes become liable. For goods temporarily imported for the Olympics, the bill requires submission of a formal application to Customs which contains details of the importer and the goods to assist in the audit and acquittal of the eventual export. This bill is important as it puts in place measures and dates for goods that are temporarily imported for the Olympics and the Paralympics. I have noted the comments made by Senator O'Brien with regard to the activities of SOCOG, and I trust that he has taken the opportunity to raise those same issues with the Labor government administra tion in New South Wales. I commend the bill to honourable senators.

talk.start.para: —This legislation has some history in that most foreign international carriers operating into Australia are not subject to the Rome Convention of 1952, which was well intentioned at the time and was designed to limit the liability on industry arising from damage to persons and property on the ground. In the time when the convention was drawn up, the industry was in its infancy, and it is arguable that it was inappropriate for the industry to be required to meet the extent of the compensation that might be necessary in some of the greater calamities that might have occurred. However, the position has now changed, and that limitation is no longer valid. It is especially inappropriate when prompt and adequate compensation is to be considered for innocent victims of air accidents.

speech.para: The involvement of the non-flying public who are injured as third parties on the ground is obviously not a matter of their choice. A 1952 convention should not be applied to them at this stage. As far as the opposition is concerned, what also highlights the situation as to the need for change is that the situation that applies when operators of aircraft registered in non-convention countries fly over Australian territory is quite different. While these operators are also subject to strict liability, there is no statutory limit to the compensation payable by them. As a consequence of these circumstances and Australia's adherence to the Rome Convention, damages received by victims of an accident caused by an Australian registered aircraft—such as Qantas or Ansett—on an international flight are likely to be substantially less than if an aircraft of a non-convention country—such as Japan, the UK or the United States—was involved. This variation in the levels of compensation creates uncertainty, can increase the costs on the judicial system and on the parties, and can increase the levels of litigation necessary to obtain better compensation.

This bill will have the effect of making all aircraft coming within its jurisdiction subject to strict and unlimited liability, and it will bring them into line with the great majority of foreign carriers who serve the Australian market and aircraft in the majority of Australian states. As this will require the repeal of current legislation, this bill needs to be passed—that is, the current legislation giving effect to the Rome Convention needs to be set aside. Australia's participation in the convention will be formally renounced, as I understand it, at a time consistent with the new act coming into force. The opposition supports these measures and commends the bill to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Sports Commission Amendment Bill 1999 is designed to facilitate the exchange of information between the Sports Commission and the Australian Customs Service about the importation of, or any attempt to import, perform ance enhancing substances. The Labor Party support this legislation as it is a continuation of the policies first introduced by Labor earlier this decade when we established ASDA—the Australian Sports Drug Agency. When ASDA was established by the Labor Party, it signalled the first time in the world that a drug agency had been created under government legislation. Its purpose was to ensure that Australian athletes were able to compete and perform in an environment unpolluted by performance enhancing substances.

speech.para: Performance enhancing drugs and other substances that are illegally used in competitive sport have caused a great deal of damage to both international and domestic sporting competitions. When ASDA was first created, one of the key aims of the then Labor government was for the agency to act as a deterrent to any athlete who might consider using prohibited substances. To achieve this goal, ASDA implemented a variety of strategies based on policy advice, education, advocacy and deterrence. In 1996-97, ASDA performed a record number of anti-doping tests. Its dominance in preventing the use of illegal substances in sport is such that ASDA now estimates that 99 per cent of athletes have been deterred from participating in banned doping practices since its programs began. The success of Australia's Sports Drug Agency is highlighted by the fact that it has not had a single successful legal challenge against its testing programs.

We are proud that ASDA has proven itself to be worthy of the exceptional international reputation it has gained. The Australian Sports Commission Amendment Bill 1999 seeks to build on this platform created by Labor. Its stated purpose is to enhance the Sports Commission's role in working with other sporting organisations to provide a competitive environment untainted by performance enhancing drugs. The main provisions in this bill are designed to establish a structure that facilitates the exchange of information about the importation of banned substances from the Australian Customs Service to the Sports Commission. This information that Customs will be supplying to the Australian Sports Commission will not be about individual athletes that have been confirmed as drug cheats, rather the information will detail situations where there exists a possibility of an offence being committed.

There are, however, a few aspects of the bill that are still to have the procedural aspects finalised, and we will take the government's assurances that these measures will be properly enacted. First, there is the vexed question of what actually constitutes a performance enhancing drug. ASDA and the Therapeutic Drugs Administration are well positioned to provide these details, particularly as the nature of what is considered performance enhancing does change depending on circumstances. Nevertheless, the government should have provided concrete definitions in this legislation. Some recent incidents involving sportspeople demonstrate that some substances that may be legally used outside of competitive sport are nevertheless illegal if used by competitive athletes. To their credit, the government have already implemented the Australian Sports Commission Amendment Bill 1999 , which establishes an Australian Sports Drug Medical Advisory Committee to adjudicate on situations where athletes need to take medically prescribed drugs that may also be deemed to be performance enhancing.

The second issue of concern that we have with this bill is privacy. The bill outlines fairly restrictive conditions covering privacy. However, an analysis of the bill shows that there is no provision for any redress if an individual has personal information unlawfully disclosed. We have been assured that all privacy measures will be strictly observed and that the Privacy Commission has given the nod to this legislation. Although the government could have done more in this respect, we are satisfied that the appropriate privacy legislation will be sufficient to ensure protection of our athletes.

Given that Australia is hosting the next Olympics and that we have an excellent international reputation for dealing with drugs in sport, Labor will support this bill without amendments. Yet we remain disappointed that the Minister for Sport and Tourism has not treated this issue with the serious policy consideration that it deserves. It was both disappointing and demoralising that the minister failed to attend the IOC World Conference on Drugs in Sport in Lausanne in February this year. The proposed drug summit that has been mooted by the minister is no substitute for attendance at this conference and for arguing Australia's position on the international stage. The IOC has a seemingly ambiguous position on the use of drugs in sport and the Australian government should have done its utmost to ensure that all practicable support was provided.

In supporting this bill, the opposition is mindful of the way this government has slashed funding to the Sports Commission and has not allocated new funding to ASDA to facilitate changes to its operations. The government must ensure that additional budgetary pressures do not compromise the other essential functions of the agency. We would not like to see a situation in which ASDA's ability to continue testing national and international competitors is in any way undermined because of stretched resources.

On a more positive note, we welcome the tenets of this bill which will establish a mechanism for the exchange of information between the Australian Customs Service and ASDA for the purposes of assisting with the agency's testing program and activities. The opposition is confident that the necessary complementary Customs legislation will be both adequate and competent.

It should be noted that the government intends to increase the level of administrative and coordination support that the Australian Customs Service provides to ASDA in relation to the illegal importation of banned sports drugs. Given this increase in functions, we urge the government to address the issue of resourcing and to ensure that Customs officials are provided with adequate training with respect to locating and reporting the importation of performance enhancing drugs in sport.
Labor will support the passage of this legislation. It will help ensure that the 2000 Olympics and competitive sport in general will be free from illegal substances.

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Lundy for her comments. The government will certainly take note of the points she has outlined, particularly those of an administrative nature that will need ongoing surveillance and scrutiny.

speech.para: The amendments in this bill will enhance the overall effectiveness of Australia's anti-doping regime and help to keep us at the forefront of the international fight against the use of banned drugs in sport. The bill will facilitate the exchange of necessary information between two key Australian agencies, thereby improving the whole of government effort to rid sport of drug cheats. I think the Minister for Sport and Tourism, Ms Kelly, is to be commended for achieving this whole of government arrangement that is so important and for her pioneering in this area.

Work being done in concert with the provisions in the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Act 1999 commenced on 1 August, allowing for Customs to pass certain sports drug related information to the Australian Sports Drug Agency. The amendments have been developed in close consultation with, and agreed to by, the Attorney-General's Department and the Privacy Commissioner to ensure that the rights to privacy continue to be protected.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) Single voyage permits (SVPs) and continuing voyage permits (CVPs) may be issued to unlicensed vessels to engage in a trade between ports where:
(a) no licensed ship is available for the service; or
(b) that the service as carried out by the licensed ships is inadequate;

A SVP application for an oil, chemical or LPG tanker must be accompanied by an independent inspection report based on the Oil Companies Interna tional Marine Forum (OCIMF) inspection standards, together with a letter from the charterer stating that the ship is in a satisfactory condition to undertake the intended shipment.

An application for dry bulk carriers requires a bulk ship inspection report to accompany the application. In addition a declaration by the charterer is required that on the basis of information provided the vessel is believed to be suitable for the intended voyage. Both oil and bulk vessels are now required to submit International Safety Management Certificates and documents of compliance issued by their Flag State.
As part of the permit approval process, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) is required to assess the documentation accompanying each application.

AMSA may not necessarily carry out an inspection on a vessel merely because it has been issued with a permit. The procedure is that if a vessel is due for inspection in accordance with AMSA's port state control (PSC) targeting strategy, then every effort is made to carry out an inspection. If the vessel is not due for inspection and no adverse reports have been received then it is unlikely that an inspection is carried out.

To obtain the specific information sought in Senate Question No. 1172, AMSA would need to obtain the names of all vessels issued with SVPs and CVPs for the period 1 July 1995 and 30 June 1999. It would require AMSA to manually check approximately 2,500 records to determine which foreign flagged vessels issued with an SVP or CVP were subject to an inspection by AMSA. This task would be extremely time consuming and I do not believe that it would be an appropriate use of AMSA's resources, particularly bearing in mind that AMSA is funded by industry through the collection of levies.

talk.start.para: the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 July 1999:

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The function of the Marine Incident Investigation Unit is to investigate the circumstances and causes of marine incidents falling within Commonwealth jurisdiction. The Unit operates within the provision of the Navigation (Marine Casualty) Regulations, made pursuant to the Navigation Act 1912, sub-section 425 (1)(ea) and sub-section 425 (1AAA).
(b) Six staff.
(c) The staff consist of:
two master mariners, both with command experience, one holding an Extra Master Mariners Certificate (degree equivalent);
two marine engineers class 1 holding degrees in mechanical engineering, with experience as chief engineer;
an ASO 4 publications officer;
an ASO 2 general administrative support officer.

(2) The unit was not asked to investigate the Red Baron incident or the death of Mr Nicky Whelan. Fishing vessel operation and safety come under State or Territory jurisdiction and only fall within the provisions of the Navigation Act, 1912, when on an overseas voyage. The Unit normally investigates incidents involving fishing vessels only when some other vessel, which comes under the provisions of the Navigation Act 1912, is also involved in the incident, such as in the case of collision.

(3) Mr Willey did not investigate the Red Baron incident. The General Manager of the then Maritime Safety and Environment Services group of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) requested Mr Willey to undertake an internal analysis of AMSA's search and rescue response to the incident.
(4) As near as can be determined, Mr Willey was requested at the beginning of March 1996 to undertake the internal analysis.

(5) See (3) above. With regard to the internal analysis, Mr Willey was a qualified and experienced search and rescue officer in the then Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre (MRCC). At that time, Mr Willey had spent a total of ten years in search and rescue, nine of them within the MRCC and one year in the search and rescue policy section.

(6) To AMSA's knowledge, no. AMSA requested Coopers and Lybrand, AMSA's internal auditors at the time, to prepare a report on the allegations that the minutes of a meeting between Airservices Australia and AMSA in relation to the Red Baron incident had been altered. While not regarded as consultants, AMSA has engaged counsel and solicitors to provide legal advice associated with the loss of the Red Baron.
